description: Multiple Features Dataset: Morphological. One of six datasets describing features of handwritten numerals (0-9) extracted from Dutch utility maps. This dataset contains 6 morphological features computed from the digit images. Each class has 200 instances digitized from binary images.
creator: Robert P.W. Duin, Department of Applied Physics, Delft University of Technology

feature_descriptions.all_features: Six morphological features capturing structural and shape properties of handwritten digits. These features are derived from mathematical morphology operations on the binary digit images.

feature_scale: Continuous numeric values representing morphological measurements
use_case: Handwritten digit recognition using morphological features. Applications include comparing effectiveness of different feature types, building ensemble classifiers, and studying minimal feature sets for digit recognition.
data_generation: Handwritten numerals from Dutch utility maps scanned at 400dpi in 8-bit grey scale, then sharpened and thresholded. Morphological features computed using mathematical morphology operations on binary images.
ethical_considerations: Dataset represents handwriting samples from Dutch utility maps, which may have specific characteristics. The small feature set (6 features) makes this dataset useful for studying feature importance and interpretability.

citations.author: M. van Breukelen, R.P.W. Duin, D.M.J. Tax, and J.E. den Hartog
citations.title: Handwritten digit recognition by combined classifiers

original_source.creator: Robert P.W. Duin, Department of Applied Physics, Delft University of Technology
original_source.publication: M. van Breukelen, R.P.W. Duin, D.M.J. Tax, and J.E. den Hartog: Handwritten digit recognition by combined classifiers

dataset_history: Dataset history not available for mfeat-morphological
inference_notes: Use Case: Handwritten digit recognition using morphological features. Applications include comparing effectiveness of different feature types, building ensemble classifiers, and studying minimal feature sets for digit recognition.
